commentBody: What a fun puzzle! Had to read the theme words out loud to get the theme. ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Still, very enjoyable. Nothing I could not get by crosses and way better than my average Wednesday. Thanks, Michael!
So a priest, a pastor, and a rabbit walk into a bar. The rabbit turns to the priest and says, "I think I'm a typo."
Fun, unique theme. Had never heard of 'Skip to my Lou' but the crossings helped. Loved the constructor notes too. RIP Velvet Thunder
Pretty sure there's been at least one tennis clue every day during the USO. Now if Fritzy can just find a way to win in five against Djokovic...

Fun, and a pretty tight theme, although I pronounce SIEGE with a strict soft g not a zh‚Äî but it is an alternate pronounciation. Here‚Äôs one that I do pronounce that way: ‚ÄúEveryone loves the Duchess of York, your highness‚Äù? ‚Äî NOBODY DOESN‚ÄôT LIKE SARAH, LIEGE. (Ok SARA LEE doesn‚Äôt gave an H‚Äî sue me.)

Andre Braugher was one of my favorite actors going back to Homicide:Life on the Streets from the 90s. I swear I would watch him read the phone book he was so talented.  Thankfully his work lives on through film.

This was soo good. Brooklyn 99, Andre Braugher‚Äôs Holt, and all the amazing quotes are staples in my home. Every time we give my dog a bone we have to yell BOOONE like Holt when he gets embarrassed at the prospect of boning. üíÄ Long live Captain Holt.

Wellll‚Ä¶ 

I‚Äôd never heard of the revealer, 
Didn‚Äôt know the deli,
And was not familiar with the HIV med. 

And that made for a very difficult center section.

But, it was a fun puzhle, nonetheless.

Hmm, I liked the puzzle more when I was doing it than when I read the column, where the theming made me wince...  It's a little much.  But I enjoyed and appreciated the constructor notes.  That show is on my growing "yeah I should probably watch" list.

Hmm, new bug or something?  I was told I'd completed a Wednesday puzzle with no mention of a streak.  I checked stats and it seems intact...

ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
I finished it but something isn't right! I can't for the life of me figure out what it is, but I don't want to use check puzzle!
Schnazzee theme, methinks.
Oh, my. I will never hear the happy music again in quite the same way. If you don‚Äôt know what I mean, read the constructor‚Äôs comments.

Sam, ETON is not a college in the sense we know colleges to be, even though it‚Äôs called ETON College. Our colleges and universities are just called universities in the UK, while anything called a college over there is what we would call a prep school here. In other words, it‚Äôs for roughly high school age boys. And it is for boys only; additionally, it is a boarding school.

Quick and clever puzzle. I was planning to say that TIL how to spell ZHUZH, but Sam's intro makes it clear there isn't just one way. For those who've never heard of "Skip to My Lou," it's a song some of us learned as kids, but I'd forgotten it's also in, "Meet Me in St. Louis," a musical I tried out for in Junior High but sadly didn't get cast. üò≠ https://youtu.be/_ywr15C7eLM?si=QK6vHAAxbn1kzBjM It's okay. I sang "Pink Pony Club" for karaoke last night and brought the house down. (In my own mind, anyway.)

That unusual sound is a pleasure to say. I had some confusion at 26A and my first guess was onetwo. TAPTAP is perfect. And ETON today vs my guess for ELON yesterday. All in all this was a treasure. 
Thank you, Michael Berg

First of all, I love that this was dedicated to Andre Braugher.  When I first saw him in "Homicide:  Life on the Streets" back in the 90s, I thought he was going to be a mega star.

But somehow it never happened.  I can't figure out why.  I'm glad he found a role on Brooklyn 99, but my honest appraisal is that his talent was mostly wasted on comedy--he was so, so good in dramatic roles.

The puzzle itself, though I solved it in reasonable time, seems to be in this era's hardening of the early week puzzles, and easing (I'm told) on the late week.  I thought this was  a difficult puzzle, although there were some absolute gimmes as well.

ZHUZHUP was a difficult cross with KATZ, which is probably the most New York City-centric clue I've ever seen.  I've been there multiple times.  I'm sure it's a landmark but I have never heard of it, as far as I know, in any of the multitude of movies set in New York City.  I hope to hear what movies did mention it.

["That slaps," for something good, e.g."] took me forever to parse, because I did not know the SLANG term.  Mostly crosses and guesses.

I'll try to be plain--I did not enjoy this puzzle as much as I have others, but nevertheless it was a great diversion from the horror of the time.  If I could pass all my time this way, I might survive.

So thank you,  Michael B. Berg.

THE DEAD SIEGE was a monumental stretch to The Dead Sea.  But it was in line with the others (I realized when I went back) so I've gotten myself to be ok with it.

Sam the Sapient notes that POPTHEHOOD is a debut. I wonder how often POPTHETRUNK has turned up. I imagine we all know it much better from all those cop shows where the hood popper is rewarded with...something unpleasant.
Raise you hand if you've never heard of ZhUZH, let alone ever done it.
Not my favorite

"Want to try out for the winter Olympics?"
"Sure, I've got nothing to luge!"

(It's easier sled than done.)
Today‚Äôs theme: Dad jokes.

Before figuring out the theme, I thought maybe ‚ÄúTampa beige‚Äù was an actual color. You know, like ‚ÄúEl Paso ecru‚Äù or ‚ÄúPeoria puce‚Äù.

But then the other themers set me straight -Bingpot! to quote Captain Holt.
I had to check to make sure I hadn‚Äôt been mispronouncing ‚Äúsiege‚Äù for the last 50 years.
BUCKAROUGE reminds me of a family joke: Every summer my dad asks at the farm stand if they still have "Pirate corn". (It costs a buck an ear).
I was not on same wave length as the puzzle maker. Struggled.

‚ÄúIt plays a little song when you solve it, as if you‚Äôve just learned to potty.‚Äù

Amazing. LOL. I turned that song off in settings. But I master to turn it back on. 

My favorite part of the solve was remembering playing pitfall on the star Atari. Man. That took me back. Thank you
Just meh
A bit of a yikes here (for a Wednesday.) Way slower than my average, and if I hadn‚Äôt been 99% sure of AZT I‚Äôd never have gotten that middle.

My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/09/02/wednesday-september-3-2025/#ny I also reviewed Tuesday's puzzle. As always, Fiend covers about half a dozen puzzles each day ‚Äî¬†some from mainstream media, some indie. Come by and learn about some fun puzzle you might otherwise have missed. (Speaking of which, the LAT puzzle from Friday, August 29, is a lot of fun.)

Is it Thursday already?

there is pleasure derived in knowing that of all the words that will go to the the pit of forgotten and useless terms ZHUZHUP  will be there in alphabetical order. 

Nice puzzle otherwise. No idea what 23A refers to but don‚Äôt care üòÄ
Didn‚Äôt the term ZHUZH UP originate on Queer Eye? I remember Jonathan using it a few seasons ago.

Believe me when I say that after a long day, BUsK A ROUGE made sense, although in a ‚Äúhuh?‚Äù, head-scratching sort of way. BUsK is a pretty rare word when used as a transitive verb. As in, ‚ÄúHe busked him al so swi√æe Bo√æe squier and kni»ùt‚Äù level of rare. 

And so I took a minute to figure out the theme, and then the penny dropped. Phew. 

I was prompted to read the constructor‚Äôs notes after reading one of the comments, and it‚Äôs only now I find out that Andre Braugher died almost two years ago! What a devastating loss. I always perked up to see his name in the credits; such talent on the screen, with warmth, intellect, and easy good humor that came just shining through. Rest in peace, Mr. Braugher.

A punny theme introduced by a phonetic clue, which solves to a phrase unknown to me - a puzzle can hardly get any worse for me, so personally I didn't like it at all ü§∑üèΩ

The poodle puppy Lucyfer (Lucifer) is beginning his third day with us. It's amazing how smart he is! He observes everything intently, learns new things and acts upon it. Case in point: Yesterday he went down the stairs for the first time in his life. In the morning he took it slow and easy, and needed encouragement. In the afternoon he didn't even stop once on his way down, and in the evening he was running down enthusiastically. Also, he is very different from Jorge the lab, which will prevent unhealthy comparisons with him. Us getting to know one another is going to be quite the adventure!
No idea about ZHUZHUP, so I had 31D as PaN, amongst others. On to tomorrow!
Not for me today. The reveal through the notes left me with a huh ? So onto tomorrow

Started solving the NYT crossword just over a week ago and today was my first 7 day streak! Nice to swap out doomscrolling with something that actually makes me feel I'm getting smarter (if only because as a Brit in Sweden there are a lot of US or NYC-specific things I have to Google). 
I enjoyed this one while solving and enjoyed it even more when I read the constructor's notes. Will have to rewatch.
Nine-nine!!!!!!

This might be the first time I've almost completely filled out the puzzle, understood the answers and their connections, and had no idea how to fill out the middle due to not knowing Katz or AZT, but I did enjoy learning something new.
Now I‚Äôm imagining Captain Holt getting Zhuzed up on Queer Eye and I‚Äôm giggling. I enjoyed this punny puzzle.

Some years ago on a trip to NY, I had lunch at Katz's followed by dinner at Peter Luger's... probably shaved a few years off my life with that combo.

Minor nit to pick with 49A - to me, gunning an engine = revving it, i.e. done in neutral (or in park, but not in gear). One might actually put the pedal to the metal while gunning an engine, but to me, that phrase = FLOORS IT

Found this a little hit and miss, but that‚Äôs because I‚Äôm not into puns rather than a fault in the puzzle. As always I‚Äôm amazed at the skills used in producing a crossword grid.

Surprised at how many haven‚Äôt heard of ZHUZH UP. In the early 90‚Äôs we had a tv programme here featuring a young, gay Asian man by the name of Gok Wan. Fabulously camp and a genuine admirer of women, he would take a woman who had lost her way sartorially speaking and teach her how to ZHUZH herself up, starting with the right underwear and building up. It was must watch tv in our house.
I believe the term comes from Polari; pre gay rights speak when it was illegal to love who you love.  I found it bitter sweet to see both this and AZT in the same puzzle. Sad for the guys who had to live in the Dark Ages, happy that they are (mostly) in the past. Though certain former democratic governments are trying their best to reverse that.
Michael, you had me smiling at TAMPA BEIGE, and kept smiling throughout, themes and fills both!
What a fun and original theme idea. Nice job, Michael! I hope to see you back soon. Kaitlin Butts, "Buckaroo": https://youtu.be/8Akpci3OuQ4?si=dURAaMRrICViqL3g

Speaking of ATE UP, I‚Äôm still laughing over a line I read from a recent movie review.  I‚Äôm sharing it because I hope it brightens your day as much as it did mine.

The review was a dire pan, and here‚Äôs the line: ‚ÄúPeople are going to want to walk out of this movie even when it is shown on airplanes.‚Äù
This puzzle led me on a deep dive on the origins of "zhuzh," which I was not familiar with. Seems it comes from Polari, a British slang. Look it up; it's fascinating.
Love Andre Braugher (RIP), loved the theme, loved the puzzle!
I wound up trying to say these phrases in Sean Connery‚Äôs voice: SHKIP TO MY LUGE.
‚ÄúWhy would you intentionally spill beans? They're one of nature's most densely packed protein sources, and they remain unsullied by flavor.‚Äú
What a nice way to start a Wednesday! Love Brooklyn Nine Nine:)

"The shoddy sandwich knife couldn't cut the mustard,"
Can someone point out the PUN in this?

In the vicinity of dad jokes - should have been right up my alley (oops). Most of it came together with some pondering but got stuck in a couple of places. And then there was the reveal. That was a completely unfamiliar term. And.. I guess I've heard of KATZ but it wasn't dawning on me, and... AZT was completely unfamiliar. So,.. cheated a bit. 

No big deal. I'll probably bomb tomorrow to end my streak. 

....

Well, I love wordplay and I love the zh sound, so this theme hit my happy button.  

There were ancillary pleasures as well.  That lovely phrase POP THE HOOD.  That sweet dook REDANTS.  Having ‚ÄúRit‚Äù, a word I haven‚Äôt seen since childhood, pop into my head as if I used it yesterday.  Seeing TAPTAP backwards and imagining someone saying, ‚ÄúThere, there.‚Äù

So, thumbs up.

Props to Michael for coming up with this collage of theme answers and getting them to fit puzzle symmetry.  That had to be tough, truly, try coming up with more.  My favorite was THE DEAD SIEGE because of its perfect clue [Headline during a zombie attack?].

In case you‚Äôre wondering, and I‚Äôm sure you are, the theme sound ‚Äì that ZH as in Zhivago ‚Äì is called a voiced postalveolar fricative, as I learned post-puzzle.  I love the beauty it adds to our language in words such as corsage, mirage, massage, and genre.

As well as in the phrase joie de vivre, which is what you brought to the box today, Michael.  Thank you!

Stalling sounds? Snort.
I love seeing the photos Sam picks to illustrate the column. And it seems to me that Deb and Caitlin have upped their photo game in response.

The fill and clues in the puzzle felt aimed at the Boomer-and-older demographic, but the fancy revealer at 38A was new-fangled talk. The contrast added zip and snap to the puzzle.

The BLIP HOLA BAR must be a good times dive.
KATZ is missing an S, while SATS should not have an S.

1. Karz‚Äôs pastrami, say no more
2. I‚Äôll have what she‚Äôs having

‚ÄúIt plays a little song when you solve it, as if you‚Äôve just learned to potty.‚Äù

 Now I will think of this every time I finish a puzzle. 

Perfect.

I like today's theme because I love the word ZHUZH.  In my world, it not only means to "fancify", but also to "poof up" or tease (with respect to one's hair).  And my mother used ZHUZH to talk about her food processor, which she called the ZHUZHer, as in "It's so easy to make chopped liver now.  You just throw all the ingredients in the ZHUZHer."

However, one must have a nit!
Today's nit-du-jour (please pardon the redundancy):
BEIGE, LUGE, and ROUGE all end with a "zh"-sound.
But SIEGE???  In my pronunciation, it ends with a "j"-sound.

Do others pronounce "SIEGE" with a ZH?

Francis, You posted this in a reply hours ago: I've seen it, and the only thing I remember is that seen. So did Sally do her performance at KATZ? And, really, was the name of the deli a prominent part of the movie? I'm sure it was easy for all the Jewish New Yorkers, but I grew up in the midwest. So, while it's entirely fair, it was a very difficult clue. (1) Any New Yorker would likely know Katz's, and orthodox Jews don't eat there because it's not a kosher deli. (2) It's been around for a while: https://katzsdelicatessen.com/ (3) It has been seen in more than one movie.

KATZ's was an iconic New York deli, even before "When Harry Met Sally" came out (in 1989!).  After the movie came out, it was (and often still is) mobbed with tourists.

They serve a nice pastrami sandwich, and the meat is hand carved, which is impressive considering how much meat they go through, but, for my money, I prefer 2nd Ave Deli (and Pastrami Queen).
Remember to tip your carver...and don't ask for mayo!
And eat a pickle; it's good for you.
Found the SE tricky given I held onto DYAD and FADES for so long :(
Crossing Katz with zhuzh up was a bit cruel for a Wednesday, for us non-native English speakers

Fun puzzle! I first heard the word ZHUZH from Rachel Ray, who was always giving food a ZHUZH on her cooking show.

I especially loved the dedication to Andre Braugher. Brooklyn Nine-Nine was an excellent show, and he was the heart of it. He had a rare skill: delivering incredibly silly lines in a manner that was dead serious. We lost him far too soon.
Every time that song plays (as it did today), I think about that moment from Brooklyn 99. I miss Andre Brauer on a daily basis.

If there is still any doubt about ZHUZH, it appeared today in my edition of the NYT International Edition. But was in the print edition last week - August 27. "Hispi ‚Äúpretty much stays across the board, the same price most of the year round,‚Äù Mr. Hill said. Its rise, he added, comes as a wave of chefs are zhuzhing up once-overlooked ingredients like secondary cuts of meat or fish for stock that once may have seemed too basic to serve diners." https://www.nytimes.com/2025/08/26/dining/london-cabbage.html?unlocked_article_code=1.jE8.xu_B.Yg_fxu6cTikC&smid=url-share
Perfect Wednesday! Hit the average, great theme and cluing. Thanks!
I sure love it when its natick city in the crossword

The very notion that American IDOL is the most-watched television show in the world diminishes my faith in humanity. I've never watched it, apart from the clip of William Hung singing "She Bangs." I've never seen the dragon movie either, but it amuses me that they would be afraid of EELS. Thumbs up to the constructor for zhuzhing up tired fill with a fresh clue. (Did I use it correctly?}
It was unique.  Just a minor quibble, if that's ok.   Siege doesn't fit the pattern.  It's pronounced seej, not seezh.  (I'd never heard actually anyone say "zhuzh up" but maybe that's just me!)

If only the fda properly regulated cosmetics üò≠ 

Loved the puzzle tho!

The emus won't let anything by me get through.  I'll summarize it as it seems to be going through an emu gut.

Love the dedication to Andre Braugher.  Highly underrated actor.

Thought KATZ was the most NYC-centric clue/answer ever.

And to cross it with ZHUZHUP was downright devilish.

["That slaps," for something good, e.g.] took me forever to parse and I got it mostly by crosses and guesses.  "That slaps"??? WTH?

I really, really, really hate the emus, who probably won't let this one through, either.

Banzai, Buckaroo Banzai, said no one in that movie. (Did Buckaroo attend ETON at the same time as James Bond?)(No.)

Fun puzhle. Nice tribute to Andre the other giant.

Buck-a-rouge makes me think of:

Feed the birds, tuppence a bag
Tuppence, tuppence, tuppence a bag
Feed the birds, specially emus 
Otherwise all of your posts you shall lose

add Mike Berg to the "not doing this puzzle" list

ZHUZH as a central theme should get me a refund for the year
It's unfortunate that Arlo Guthrie is mentioned in the past tense since he's still very much with us.
That was a breeZH! What fun!

Put me in the minority. I did not like it. I felt like  although the theme was loosely connected by sounding like another phrase the crosses near the theme entries were obscure. 

Seems more appropriate for a Thursday or Friday.

I had to go to the Column to finish my revealer: _HU_HUP.  It's hard for me to believe that's really an expression. I suppose, though, that running the (entire) alphabet just once would have sufficed.

I like the word zhuzh and that there's a whole NYT article about it! Also enjoyed the write-up and the connection to our beloved game and editor. Not being familiar with Katz deli, I got stuck with one letter off thinking "I lose" also worked for a cry of defeat. Thanks for the fun puzzle!
i like the puns but too many proper nouns killed the solve... great idea, less so in execution
Fun puzzle!  Loved that my college (Carleton) got a mention.
I have a print from the TATE MODERN hanging on the wall right next to me, and yet all I could think was "Who is Tate Modern?" ü§¶üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
Feel like skip to my lou is too obscure to work as one of the theme entries in a puzzle like this

I must say that this was one of the least enjoyable crosswords I have done.  Is ZHUZH really a word? It‚Äôs asinine if it is. Theme was terrible!  A crossword is a crossword, not an exercise in futility!
off the chart NO - AZT is not and never was an approved hiv medication it was meant to harm and that's all it did - BOO!

This was so difficult for me! Like (trying to) solve 6 months ago.
Just too many terms I didn't know, and I didn't get the link between revealer and theme at all. Entirely my fault, of course. 

I've never heard the term ART MUSEUM, surely it's a gallery?

I actually know 'Skip to my Lou' from primary school, but the other long clues were beyond me! TAMPA BEIGE?

Also, SLAPS, NASH< POP THE HOOD (I know now it means 'open the bonnet'), HIT ON  for 'happen upon', and DEUCE didn't come to mind.

Sigh. Can't win them all.
ZHUZHUP crossing KATZ and AZT is a little too trivia-y for my liking.

A few really hard squares in this puzzle, I've never heard of ZHUZH UP.

I had the most trouble though in the bottom left corner.  HI HAT is very specialized knowledge and it's crossed with HIT ON which is a bit of an awkward phrasing and ETON which is just as obscure.  I first guessed ELON just because it was an equally obscure college related answer a couple days ago.

This puzzle took me twice as long as my Wednesday average just because there's a few many really awkward phrasings.

i got all the theme entries but missed the revealer.  There are some expressions you simply can't know if you lack the right amount of body art, and ZHUZH UP has to be one of them.  It occurs to me I may have to swallow my pride and ink up to stay competitive in this game.
Nope

I have no issues with zhuzh up, I‚Äôve even used it myself and I don‚Äôt even mind the theme, I picked up on it early and they easily fell into place and made me smile.  What I do struggle with is all the proper nouns (I only knew SBC - which probably says more about me than the puzzle üòÅ) but so many of them, 8, I think which is nearly 13% of the clues (I worked this out in my old head so don‚Äôt shout if I‚Äôm wrong).

I only read a few recent comments but saw that at least some solvers hadn‚Äôt heard of ZHUZH. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever used it in conversation, but I have certainly come across it before in crosswords, so it seemed more than fair to me. I really enjoyed the clever theme üëèüèªüòä
My final spot to fall was 48D. I had tried ‚Äúout‚Äù and ‚Äúnet‚Äù before getting it right, mostly because I had seen what was going on with the theme fill. 
Thanks for the fun, Michael Berg.

I‚Äôm relatively new to solving ‚Äî I got a ‚≠êÔ∏è for Monday and Tuesday‚Äôs puzzles but had to resort to my old friend autocheck for today. The bottom left corner really threw me for a loop. Oh well, there‚Äôs always tomorrow!

Oof, I didn‚Äôt have a lot of fun with this one. Centering your puzzle on ZHUZHUP is‚Ä¶ certainly a choice, especially when it doesn‚Äôt really have anything to do with the highlighted phrases (but, this seems to be par for the course for these creators who somehow get their puzzles published). I thought the rest of the cluing was fine, if a bit naticky in parts. Overall a very ‚Äúmeh‚Äù experience, and a puzzle I hope to forget by tomorrow. :)
Did not like it. AZT crossing ZHUZHUP did me in. Rough week NYT crossword-wise in general, and it‚Äôs only Wednesday. But otherwise things are good, so I‚Äôve got that going for me.
Tedium. Crosswords should be clever and fun. 0 for 2. Also, in what language can I find ZHUZUP?
He had me at Andre Braugher and Will Shortz.  Nice memories.
Not having heard of zhuzh or ZHUZH UP was not a showstopper for me, but perhaps it, along with the theme answers, slowed me down.  Took 14% longer than average to solve.

I was surprised so many people disliked the puzzle. I loved it, and the shout out to Andre Brouwer.

Seeing the vitriol, I read up on zhuzh. It was added to the oed online in 2005, so has been around for a while.

And it surprises me that people get grumpy because they don‚Äôt know a word in a puzzle, rather than pleased that they learned something new.

This has already been discussed, hours ago, but it's worth noting the opening sentence of the Wikipedia article on Eton:

"Eton College is a public school providing boarding education for boys aged 13‚Äì18."

Or, to put it in plain English, a private high-school.
I got the clue for Zhuzh right away, but had never seen it spelled so it took a while to fill in those squares

This theme was cleverrr! Also loved the clue: Reason for a tucked tail, perhaps 
:*-)

BUCKAROUGE is definitely my favorite!

I loved the constructor's notes very much. Captain Holt is my Peacock profile pic, but sadly the subscription price is going up again and it's likely one of the first we'll LOP. (Once we finish Poker Face. And a rewatch of Nine-Nine. And The Phoenician Scheme. And Drop. And anything else anyone recommends. üòâ)

Thank you Mr. Berg!
I love the cute backstory about Brooklyn 99. Made this puzzle even more endearing!
Having never read or written the word ‚Äúzhuzh‚Äù, it took a couple stabs to get the spelling correct. But overall a pretty fun/quick solve.
Had to flyspeck the hell out of this puzzle thanks to my GENE rather than GENA Rowlands.  Should have noticed BUCKEROUGE faster.  A solve is a solve though.

Getting to do a bunch of puzzles with some fun wordplay in both the clues and the answers has made for a lot of laughter for both my husband and me.  We've thoroughly enjoyed the goofy puns and silliness liberally sprinkled throughout the puzzles!  Thanks for the fun, puzzle creators and editors.  It's been a blast!  Today was no exception.
I love the tribute to Andre Braugher! A comedic titan gone far too soon <3
Hmm, I decline to bestow my seal approval on that one.

This might have been my favourite puzzle so far. The theme words made sense, the theme clues were good, and even the fills were fresh and interesting. I think "Fairy tale baddie" was the only real chestnut I spotted. And what a treat to imagine Captain Holt doing the puzzle and getting that little tune.
I will say it's really wild seeing how many people have no idea what AZT is, if you are Of A Certain Age.

This was a fun one. If felt fast because I was always making progress but come in right around average. 

I had read a few comments about SEIGE fitting the theme. It worked for me but I had a chance to get one more opinion. I asked my wife what it is called when an army surrounds a castle. She said 
‚ÄúSeezh‚Äù. 
 I told her why I asked and she said that she definitely also pronounced it ‚ÄúseeJ‚Äù sometimes. 

I had SaSha at 53D crossing -uSkarouge. What kind of currency is this dollar store using?!? 
Of course, a Buck, Buck, BUCKAROUGE!! 
Simply awesome!!

I think it's worth pointing out that the only reason I know how to spell "zhuzh" is because I'm pretty sure it's been in a different crossword. The word itself is pretty common but I would never have guessed it's spelled like that (I think I would guess something like "jugh" or "jujj" because it sounds more like a J to me) - just saying because I bet a lot of the people who think they've never heard of it have heard it, just never seen it written down! (And I don't live anywhere near New York so I don't think that's it.)

Late checking in.  Life getting in the way of the puzzle again.  Need to fix that.  

Being able to guess "SKIPTOMYLUGE" with just a few crossers will keep the ego juices flowing for some time.  

Clever and fun wordplay.  Nicely done.

And here it is, 10:13 pm EDT, and the Thursday column is not up yet. 

When this happens, it always seems to be the Thursday column. I wonder why?

Oof, still no Thursday Wordplay link. I really want to know if everyone else was as impressed with the Thursday puzzle as I was‚Ä¶ great stuff and one of my all time faves! (No disrespect to Wednesday though, which I also enjoyed.)

I enjoyed the majority of this puzzle, but even though I guessed that the phrase was probably ZHUZH UP, I had no idea how to spell it. Added to that was the very regional New York deli (one of the many, many in NYC) and a dated HIV med. I‚Äôm sure people may know these, but it still feels very obscure and niche for a tricky revealer. 

Unfortunately, this was the revealer for the entire wordplay of the puzzle (which, to be honest, I also still don‚Äôt quite understand).

@Steve L Not really though. Cambridge and Oxford universities are made up of colleges. https://www.cam.ac.uk/about-the-university/how-the-university-and-colleges-work https://www.ox.ac.uk/admissions/undergraduate/colleges/a-z-of-colleges
@Andrzej I love this. I'm curious to know why they call the cardinals group, a college of cardinals. Is college also a term for group?

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight

Yes, it's from Latin, where collegium means a group of people. Actually, in Polish kolegium (which is simply a transcritpion of the Latin pronunciation into Polish) is one of the words for a group acting in some official capacity.

@Steve L You're mostly right and I appreciate the clarification but a small point: A college here is not just a prep school. That's just in private education. It more commonly refers to a place some students go for their last two years before university. Our equivalent of high school goes to 16, then you go to college or sixth form.

@Andrzej

Yes, you are correct. I just wanted to explain about schools like ETON.

@E

Thank you.  I was just trying to explain the usage as regards ETON, a ‚Äúpublic school,‚Äù  which means it is a private school. (Those two are diametric opposites in the USA.)

Actually, I like the British system better, as many students have no business being in a scholastic setting after age 16, and should be learning a trade, but the egalitarian ideals of the US work against that, so we have an overabundance of youngsters who are unhappily plodding through 11th and 12th grades, a shortage of people trained to, or willing to fill certain jobs, and therefore a need for immigrant labor, and subsequently the immigration mess we have now. 

I‚Äôm convinced there is a straight line between the movement to send everyone to college, er, university, that took hold in the 90s and our immigration troubles now.

@Eric Hougland
It is a blessing that AIDS as a deadly disease has largely receded into the past along with its treatment. I was just at the trailing edge of polio and remember lining up in the school auditorium for vaccination. I knew kids who were crippled (as we said then) and every single parent made sure that their healthy child got their shot. Does anyone under 60 know what an "iron lung" is? I sure hope not.

@Eric Hougland Actually, it's a good thing because it shows the progress that's occurred. I think it's great that a person born in the late '80s with HIV is alive and thriving today because of the Fauci trials on infants with HIV. Google Joseph A. Kibler.

@SBK

So polio also lead to mental problems.

The first time I saw an iron lung, I recoiled so badly I'm not sure how I ever calmed myself.  It was utterly terrifying.

@Francis
My favourite uncle was gay and unable to be himself for most of his life. Even when he met the love of his life in his 50‚Äôs and the laws in the UK had been repealed regarding homosexuality, they both were so conditioned to secrecy that they maintained separate lives in their shared home.
When his partner died the rest of my family couldn‚Äôt understand why David was so grief stricken, their disconnect was so total they could not accept the truth. 
I am proud to say that I have a son who identifies as gay. I cannot imagine the horror of having to hide who he truly is. I wish my uncle was still here to witness what joy there can be when you‚Äôre allowed to be yourself. 
ZHUZH is a silly word with a universe of meaning for those who know.

(3) Continued...

Katz's was the site of Meg Ryan's fake orgasm scene in the 1989 romantic comedy When Harry Met Sally..., followed by Estelle Reiner's line "I'll have what she's having"; the table at which Ryan and Billy Crystal sat is marked with a sign that says, "Where Harry met Sally... hope you have what she had! Enjoy!"[21][22]
It was the site of Johnny Depp's character meeting with an FBI contact in Donnie Brasco (1997).[23]
Katz's Deli is the site for a scene in Across the Universe (2007), in which Max reveals he has been drafted into the Vietnam War.[24]
The deli appears in the 2007 film We Own the Night, starring Joaquin Phoenix, Mark Wahlberg and Eva Mendes.[24]

(3) Continued...

In the French film Nous York (2012), Manu Payet and Dree Hemingway visit Katz's, where Fred Austin greets them at their table.
In the 2001 comedy-drama indie film Sidewalks of New York, David Krumholtz's character Benjamin and a friend wolf down a pastrami sandwich and hot dog at Katz's.[25][26]
Katz's is featured in the 2014 documentary Deli Man.[27][28]
Katz's appears in the 2004 film Looking for Kitty.[29]
In the film Off Beat (1986), a group of police officers enjoy a hot meal at the deli.[30]
The contract to kill Frank Sinatra's character in Contract on Cherry Street (1977) was drafted in a Katz's meat locker.[31]
In a scene in Enchanted (2007), Nathaniel (Timothy Spall) contacts Queen Narissa (Susan Sarandon) from Katz's kitchen and then joins Prince Edward (James Marsden) for lunch while trying to silence Pip the chipmunk from spilling his betrayal.[32]
